> >

> > challenge
>
> I think that doing GET to an "anonymous" uri and obtain an invisible
> context after authentication is not restful. Why not doing a GET to:
>
> http://my.bank/private/sj
>
> which asks for credentials (here, sj credentials)?

*sigh* sorry.  This is a mistake.  Originally, Steps 1 returned a web form
and Step 2 was a POST that created the URI.  I changed it to HTTP Auth to
avoid limiting the scope of the example to HTML.  I failed to re-read what I
changed it to, and therefore didn't catch that I was returning a 201 in
response to a GET.  So... let's go back and change that somewhat:

1) I POST my credentials to http://my.bank/access, be this from a web form,
some proprietary xml, etc.  The server authenticates me and returns a 201
with a Location of http://my.bank/access/12345.  (note: the html form could
be retrieved with a GET to http://my.bank/access.)

> > 7) Also on the screen is an option that says "send this page to:" and an
> > input box.  I fill in my accountant's e-mail address, and press
> submit.
>
> What could be done here is first to POST to the URI:
>
> http://my.bank/accountant/sj
>
> an xml document containing the uri :
>
> http://my.bank/private/sj/accounts/checking/456
>
> This POST has for effect to make the corresponding resource available
> as :
>
> http://my.bank/accountant/sj/accounts/checking/456
>
> I could then mail this uri to my accountant.
>
> If an authenticated user try to GET this, it has to be authenticated,
> and if not the user sj himself, has to own the role "accountant".
>
> Of course, the role "private" does not give any right... .

I'm not sure I understand what you are saying here.  I get the bit about
creating the URI, but not the rest.

> > The e-mailed URL would have a limited time limit such as 30 minutes,
> after
> > which, the link will only return a 404 response or some such.
> >
>
> In my mind, this create a state inside the server (a timer). This is
> bad isn't it ?

The timer is not part of the client state.  It's part of the resource state.
It's the client state that the server is not suppose to be maintaining.

By the way, the reason I created the URI instead of using HTTP Auth (or a
cookie or whatever) at all times was partly due to Tyler and his crazy
capabilities-based security model.  :)  I am not sure if I am doing it
right, but the basic idea here was that the bank issued a URI
(http://my.bank/access/12345) with a defined set of capabilities (the
"contract").  I could do anything that's defined, nothing more.  On top of
that, when I want to share part of my access, I ask the bank for another
capability URI (http://my.bank/proxy-access/56789) for that particular bit.
Like the first URI, use is limited to what is defined.  This also means that
I do not have to get my accountant set up with a separate password, flip a
potentially large set of switches to set the security context, etc. just to
give access.  Of course, this is a somewhat weak example, since most people
would likely just copy-n-paste the screen and e-mail it instead of go
through all of this effort.  But in a more complex situation, I see how this
approach could work well (I think).

Seairth
